Sepiolite as a promising nanoclay for nano-biocomposites based on starch and biodegradable polyester
J.B. Olivato a,c,⁎, J. Marini b, F. Yamashita a, E. Pollet c, M.V.E. Grossmann a, L. Article history: Received 29 May 2016 Received in revised form 21 August 2016 Accepted 29 August 2016 Available online 31 August 2016
The effects of sepiolite addition (0, 1, 3 and 5wt%) were evaluated on dynamic-mechanical behaviour, water uptake, thermal and optical properties of thermoplastic starch (TPS)/poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT) nano-biocomposites, with different TPS/PBAT (w/w) ratios and nanofiller contents. The results highlighted the improvement of the dynamic-mechanical behaviourwith the addition of sepiolite, producing high performance materials. An increase of 25 °C in the Tg of TPS was recorded by DMTA analysis at sepiolite content of 5 wt%. The sepiolite influenced the crystallisation of nano-biocomposites, without causing interference in the crystal organisation, evidenced by DSC analysis. The addition of sepiolite nanoclay decreased the water adsorption rate and water adsorption capacity of the corresponding nano-biocomposites. For such multiphase systems, the successful use of natural sepiolite brought a clear benefit, without the need of anymodifications or additional processes to produce advanced nano-biocomposites.

Keywords: Biobased materials Nanoclay Thermoplastic starch Poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) Dynamic-mechanical properties

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Academic researchers have focused on the development of environmentally friendly materials, i.e., produced from sustainable resources, with lower energy consumption, biodegradable and non-toxic to the environment [1,2].
Biopolymers from agro-resources, such as starch, has long been recognised as cheap, biodegradable and renewable materials with potential as substitute of non-biodegradable synthetic polymers for some applications [3,4]. Starch is based on two different macromolecules: amylose and amylopectin, with some by-products such as proteins or lipids found in low content. In presence of a plasticiser (e.g., polyols), with water as a destructuring agent and under thermo-mechanical treatment, the plasticised starch, also called “thermoplastic starch (TPS)”, is obtained [3,5–6].
However, the corresponding starch-based materials have some strong limitations such as poormechanical properties compared to conventional thermoplastics, long post-processing ageing, and high hygroscopicity. To overcome these drawbacks, the elaboration of multiphase systems, such as blends or composites, has been largely considered [7–10].
ecnologia de Alimentos, Centro ina, PO Box 6001, 86051-980
Poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT) is an aromatic-aliphatic biodegradable copolyester with good mechanical performance and presenting higher elongation at break than, e.g., poly (lactic acid) (PLA). Blending thermoplastic starchwith such a biodegradable polyester represents a singular alternative to overcome the TPS weaknesses and to expand their usage [11–13].
Nanosized filler incorporated into a biodegradable polymer results in nano-biocomposite materials [14] with improved mechanical, thermal and barrier properties due the high interface area to develop strong nanofiller-polymer interactions, when a good dispersion is achieved. Resulting biobased materials show improved behaviour while preserving final material biodegradability, without any (eco)toxic effects [1,8, 14–17].
Presently, most of the researches on nano-biocomposites aremainly based on highly available layered silicates with platelet-like structures, such as montmorillonite (MMT) [14,18–21].
With a needle-likemorphology, sepiolite nanoclay has been less extensively studied. It is a hydrated magnesium silicate with theoretical unit cell formula Mg8Si12O30(OH)4·(H2O)4·8H2O with an alternation of blocks and channels that grow up in the fibre direction. As reported, andwhen compared to platelet-based fillers, sepiolite, with their smaller interface surface, aremore easily dispersiblewith less agglomeration, which lead to a higher mechanical reinforcement [21].
Motivating results were recently reported in literature on sepiolitebased nano-biocomposites with TPS [22] or with PBAT matrix [12,23]. Besides more recently, preliminary simulating results were also obtained on TPS/PBAT-based nano-biocomposites, which proved the
preferential localisation of sepiolite in starch-rich phase [24]. This study complements these previous ones, focusing on the dynamic-mechanical and thermal behaviour of the nano-biocomposites and the role of sepiolite in these properties, with the aim to produce an efficient and innovative biodegradable multiphase system. Structure/properties relationships were investigated on different multiphase systems based on the association of sepiolite nanoclay into TPS/PBATmatrix. Variations of the TPS/PBAT ratio (w/w) and nanoclay content were more particularly studied. The dynamic-mechanical behaviour, thermal, water uptake and optical properties of the corresponding systems have been analysed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Native cassava starchwas obtained from Indemil (Paranavaí, Brazil). Poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT) was supplied by BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany) under the commercial name Ecoflex® and neat sepiolite (also called natural or sodium sepiolite) supplied by Tolsa (Madrid, Spain) under the commercial name of Pangel® S9, with a cationic exchange capacity (CEC) of 1050 μequiv·g−1. Glycerol supplied by Novance (Paris, France) was used as a non-volatile plasticiser.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Thermoplastic starch (TPS) preparation
sections.text: Native cassava starch was dried overnight at 70 °C in a ventilated oven and then introduced in a turbo-mixer with slow addition of a controlled quantity of glycerol, under stirring at 1700 rpm, until a homogeneousmixture was achieved. Then, themixture was dried at 170 °C in a ventilated oven for 40min to obtain a starch-based dry-blend. To obtain TPS, controlled water content was added to the dry-blend and processed in a counter-rotating internal batch mixer (Rheomix OS, Haake, USA), at 70 °C for 20 min, with a rotor speed of 150 rpm. The corresponding TPS formulation was based on 54 wt% of cassava starch, 23 wt% of glycerol and 23 wt% of water.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Elaboration of the TPS/sepiolite masterbatch
sections.text: A TPS masterbatch containing 10 wt% sepiolite was produced, with the same processing conditions of neat TPS, by the mixture of starchbased dry-blend, water and sepiolite nanoclay, and processed in a counter-rotating internal batchmixer (Rheomix OS, Haake, USA) at 70 °C for 20 min, with rotor speed of 150 rpm.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Elaboration of the TPS/PBAT blends and nano-biocomposites
sections.text: Different blends (TPS/PBAT) and nano-biocomposites were produced by mixing in a counter-rotating internal batch mixer (Rheomix OS, Haake, USA), at 130 °C for 20 min and 150 rpm. The mixtures were then compression moulded at 130 °C for 12 min and pressure of 20 MPa with a Scientific hot press (Labtech Engineering Company, Muang, Thailand) to obtain plates. Two TPS/PBAT content ratios were tested, 50:50 and 80:20 (w:w), with 0, 1, 3 and 5 wt% of sepiolite nanoclay, respectively. The TPS/sepiolite masterbatch was used to produce the corresponding nano-biocomposites. The corresponding samples were designated as X/Y/Z, where X, Y and Z are the TPS, PBAT and sepiolite nanoclay content in wt%, respectively. Reference materials based on neat PBAT and TPS were prepared with the same processing conditions. All the samples were conditioned and stabilised at 53 ± 2% relative humidity and 25 ± 2 °C for 20 days before the analysis to limit the effect of the post-processing ageing.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC)
sections.text:
A DSC Q200 (TA Instruments, New Castle, USA)was used to perform the differential scanning calorimetric analysis for all the samples. The samples were subjected to a first heating from 30 °C to 240 °C, with a further cooling to −80 °C and a new second heating cycle to 240 °C, keeping rate of 10 °C/min for all the steps, under nitrogen flow (50 mL/min). The melting (Tm), crystallisation (Tc) and glass transition (Tg) temperatures, crystallisation enthalpy (ΔHc) and melting enthalpy (ΔHm) of neat PBAT and nano-biocomposites were determined from cooling and second heating scans.
It is well-known that to obtain reproducible and significant data from DSC of starch or TPS is not obvious, since the heat capacity gap is quite low at the glass transition [25,26]. Based on this, the neat TPS has not been analysed by DSC.
The crystallinity degree (Xc %) of the samples was determined only based on PBAT fraction, according to Eq. (1).
Xc ¼ ΔHm 100ΔHo 1−wsþcð Þ ð1Þ
whereΔHm is themelting enthalpy of the sample,ΔHo is themelting enthalpy of a 100% crystalline PBAT andws + c is the weight fraction of sepiolite nanoclay and starch. The calculated ΔHo was 114 J/g [27].

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Dynamical mechanical thermal analysis (DMTA)
sections.text: A Dynamical Mechanical Analyser (DMA-Q800, TA Instruments, USA), using tensionfilm clamp,was used to determine the storagemodulus (MPa) and damping factor (tan δ) of the materials. The samples were scanned from −80 °C to 100 °C with a heating rate of 3 °C/min, fixed frequency of 1 Hz and 15 μm of amplitude. Glass transition temperature (Tg) is associated with the relaxation temperature, which was determined at the maximum of the main tan δ peak.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Moisture sorption isotherms
sections.text:
Samples of about 500 mg were previously dried for 20 days (CaCl2, RH≈ 0%) and then placed at 25±2 °C in desiccators containing saturated salt solutions, to obtain different environments with controlled relative humidity (11, 32, 53, 75 and 90% RH) [28]. Each sample was weighed until equilibrium moisture content. Guggenheim–Anderson– de Boer (GAB) model (Eq. (2)) was used to fit the data.
M ¼ mo C K aw= 1−K awð Þ 1−K aw þ C K awð Þ ð2Þ
whereM is the equilibriummoisture content, aw is thewater activity,mo is the monolayer value (g water/100 g solids) and C, K are the GAB constants. The GAB model parameters were determined by non-linear regression, using the Origin Software 8.0 (OriginLab, USA).

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Moisture adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
Samples of about 500 mg were previously dried for 20 days (CaCl2, RH≈ 0%) and then placed at 25±2 °C in desiccators containing saturated salt solutions, under different relative humidity (RH) conditions (32, 53, 75 and 90% RH) [29]. The weights of the samples were taken as a function of time and themoisture contentwas determined by oven drying at 105 °C. The moisture adsorption data were fitted to a mathematical model proposed by Peleg [30] (Eq. (3)).
M tð Þ ¼ M0 þ t=k1 þ k2:tð Þ ð3Þ
whereM(t) is themoisture after a time t,M0 is the initial moisture content, k1 is the Peleg rate constant and k2 is the Peleg capacity constant. All tests were conducted in triplicate.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Opacity and colour analysis
sections.text: The opacity and colour analysis were determined by means of a colorimeter (BYK Gardner-USA) at 10° and illuminant D65 (daylight) according to the Hunterlab methods [31]. The colour was determined on the samples placed on top of a white pattern and expressed as CIEL*a*b* values. Themeasurementswere taken from three different spots in each sample and the average of a* and b* parameters were reported. The opacity of the samples (Y)was calculated as the ratio between the opacity of the sample placed on top of a black pattern (Yb) and the opacity of the sample placed on top of a white pattern (Yw) (Eq. (4)).

sections.heading: Y ¼ Yb=Ywð Þ 100 ð4Þ
sections.text: The opacity results (Y) were divided by the sample thickness and expressed on an arbitrary scale (0–1 %·μm−1). The measurements were completed in triplicate.

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Statistical analysis
sections.text: The data were analysed using STATISTICA 7.0 software (Statsoft, Oklahoma, USA), with analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Tukey's test at a 5% significance level.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
DSC analysis was performed on PBAT, TPS/PBAT blends and all the nano-biocomposites. The main thermal data such as melting, crystallisation and glass transition temperatures are presented in Table 1. The corresponding thermograms are shown in Fig. S1.
The DSC thermogram showed a glass transition temperature (Tg) of −29 °C, melting temperature (Tm) of 127 °C and crystallinity degree (Xc) of around 13% for PBAT. By blending with TPS, the Tg decreases to −32 °C and −33 °C for 50/50/0 and 80/20/0 samples, respectively. No significant influence of the starch ratio on this Tg value was observed, which indicates no or low PBAT-TPS interaction and compatibility as previously reported [11].
The incorporation of sepiolite nanoclay did not influence significantly the Tg and Tm of the nano-biocomposites. However, a slight increase of Tg and Tm were observed between the blends and the corresponding nano-biocomposites. The effect of the nanoclay content from 1 to 5 wt% is not significant on Tg and Tm.
The blends exhibited a crystallisation peak at 79 °C (50/50/0) and 63 °C (80/20/0). The addition of sepiolite increased significantly the Tc and decreased the crystallinity content (Table 1). This last result is on agreement with Fukushima et al. [12] who observed that sepiolite reduced the crystallinity degree in PBAT matrix, possibly due to confinement effect and steric hindrance, which restrain the crystal growth. Sepiolite seems to act in the crystallisation process of the nanobiocomposites, mainly during the nucleation step. The nucleating effect of sepiolite was previously observed for different matrices, including polypropylene (PP) [21]; poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT) [12,13,32] and starch/polyester blends [33].
No difference in the melting peak of PBAT was observed, even with 5 wt% of sepiolite, which suggests that the crystal organisation formed in nano-biocomposites were similar to those of virgin PBAT. This result is on agreementwith previousworkswhere x-ray diffraction analysis of TPS/PBAT nano-biocomposites showed that, for all the samples, the crystalline structures did not change with the introduction of sepiolite nanoclay [24].
McGlashan and Halley [33] observed that the inclusion of montmorillonite in starch/polyester matrix did not induce significant changes in themelting temperature of each polymer constituent, but affected their crystallisation temperature. In the case of the nano-biocomposites (Table 1), the Tc increased with the nanoclay content.
Concerning the effect on crystallinity degree for 50/50 and 80/20 TPS/PBAT blends, Xc decreased when the nanoclay content increased. Higher sepiolite content induced a reduction of 60% crystallinity degree in the 50/50/5 sample, and 50% in the 80/20/5 sample, which seems to indicate that sepiolite, although acted as a nucleating agent, is able to limit the PBAT crystallite growth. The crystallisation behaviour of PBAT was dependent on the components and their contents present in the nano-biocomposites (Table 1). The higher proportion of starch in the materials resulted in higher crystallinity of PBAT. Regarding the influence of the sepiolite content, two behaviours can be observed: a proportional decrease in crystallinity with increasing content of sepiolite in the 50/50 TPS/PBAT blends and a crystallinity independence with sepiolite content in the 80/20 TPS/PBAT blends. Highest crystallinities were obtained for 80/20-based systems.
DMTA analysis was used to estimate the transition temperatures of TPS-basedmaterials on agreement with previous studies [26]. The storage modulus (E′) and damping factor (tan δ) versus temperature of the TPS and PBAT are presented in Fig. 1. For bothmatrices, it was observed that the E′ values decrease with the increase in temperature, showing a drastic fall around −20 °C for PBAT. For TPS, two falls were registered, the first around−60 °C and the second at 30 °C.
A single main peak of tan δ at−27 °C was recorded for PBAT, corresponding to the α-relaxation (Tα) temperature, which could be associated to the Tg. Damping factor of TPS showed two main relaxation peaks (α and β), with the maximum peak at 26 °C being associated to the starchmain relaxation transition (associated to the Tg), and the β relaxation (Tβ) at−59 °C consistent with the relaxation of the free-glycerol phase. All these results are on agreement with previous studies on TPS [26] and PBAT [13].
The storage modulus (E′) of all samples increased with the incorporation of sepiolite (Fig. 2) being this enhancement more noticeable below the Tg of TPS (26 °C). This effect was particularly clear for the 80:20 nano-biocomposites and revealed the conventional effect of nanoclay as reinforcing agent. According to previouswork [24] sepiolite ismainly localised in the TPS-rich phase. This phenomenon resulted in a more pronounced enhancement of the mechanical properties for 80:20 TPS/PBAT nano-biocomposites, with higher tensile strength and elastic modulus, while preserving the elongation at [24]. This behaviour is typical of a true nanocomposite with good nanofiller dispersion [22].
Fukushima et al. [18] observed for sepiolite-based nanocomposites higher E′ values when comparing the effect of sepiolite andmontmorillonite nanoclays in PBAT matrix. Similar results were also observed for PLA [23] and starch [22], which indicate higher performance for sepiolite, proving that sepiolite is an interestingfiller to be used in biodegradable materials, in accordance with the results exhibited in this work.
Tan δ graphs for all the nano-biocomposites are presented in Fig. 2. Three transition peaks can be identified and correspond to a simple addition of the different relaxations of PBAT and TPS, as shown in Fig. 1, which shows that there is no full compatibility between TPS and PBAT. However, we can notice a slight shift of themain relaxations comparing the neat polymers (Fig. 1) and the blends (Fig. 2), which show some slight interactions between the main phases.
Considering 50:50 TPS/PBATnano-biocomposites, the addition of sepiolite nanoclay clearly shifted the Tg of starch-rich phase, from 23 °C to 31, 40
and 48 °C with 1, 3 and 5 wt% of sepiolite, respectively. These shifts in Tg clearly attest high interfacial interactions between sepiolite and starch, resulting in a limitation of themobility of the starch chainswith a good dispersion of the nanoclay [24] and its higher compatibility with starch, as
previously discussed. This also leads to a slight increment of Tβ of the glycerol-rich phase, shifted from−59 °C (50/50/0) to−51 °C (50/50/5).
On the opposite, the main relaxation temperature of PBAT-rich phase at around 26 °C was not shifted with the addition of sepiolite.

This supports the statement that sepiolite, being more compatible with starch, was preferentially localised at TPS phase.
Contrary to the results observed for 50:50 TPS/PBAT samples, the inclusion of sepiolite nanoclay onlymarginally influenced the Tg of starchrich phase for 80:20-based nano-biocomposites (Fig. 2). At a given sepiolite content, higher TPS content led to a dilution of nanoclay particles in the starch-rich phase and then the decrease of mobility linked to the interactions starch-nanofiller was largely reduced.
On agreement with the results observed for 50:50-based nanobiocomposites and the statement concerning the sepiolite localisation, the main relaxation temperature associated to the Tg of PBAT-rich phase for 80:20-based nano-biocomposites was not modified with the inclusion of sepiolite.
Themoisture sorption isotherms at 25 °C of nano-biocomposites are presented in Fig. 3. All curves exhibited a similar shape to those observed for most of starch-based materials [28,29,34]. Moisture of the nano-biocomposites was dependent on the TPS content. Samples with highest TPS content (80:20 TPS/PBAT) adsorbed the highest water content (Fig. 3). In addition, the presence of sepiolite did not change the equilibrium water content of the materials.
Table 2 shows that GABmodel was efficient to describe themoisture sorption isotherms of the nano-biocomposites (R2 N 0.98). The monolayer value (mo) indicates the maximum amount of water adsorbed in a single layer per gram of dry material [35] that can be related to the sorption sites. The nano-biocomposites with the highest TPS content resulted in highermonolayer values (mo=5.4±2.0 gwater / 100 g solids for 80/20/0 sample). This behaviour results from the highly hydrophilic starch chains, with more sorption sites (based on hydroxyl groups).
For the 80:20 TPS/PBAT blends, in general, the addition of sepiolite slightly decreased the value ofmo, independent of the nanoclay content. The opposite trend was observed for 50:50 TPS/PBAT samples that showed a marginal increase in the monolayer values with sepiolite incorporation in matrix, with lowest value of this parameter for the unfilled 50/50/0 sample (1.55 ± 0.53 g water / 100 g solids).
Tang et al. [36] reported that the behaviour of the nanocomposites based on starch/montmorillonite clay depends on the compatibility and interactions between the polymer chains, the plasticisers and the filler. In the systems studied in the presentwork, a complex competition between the strong polar-polar interactions of starch chains, glycerol, linked water molecules and nanoclay surface takes place, resulting in a balance between these interactions, which interferes with free water molecules. The nanoclay-starch interactions decreased the availability of the hydrophilic sites, reducing thewatermonolayer values. The effect
was more pronounced in the samples with greater starch proportions (80:20).
The C parameter is related to the heat of sorption of the first layer. The K parameter is related to the heat of sorption of the multilayer. There is hardly any difference in both parameters for all the samples. The nano-biocomposites showed values of C lower than the observed by other authors for starch-based materials [19,29,37], probably because of the processing technique, the starch content and the nanostructure. As previously reported [28,34,38], K parameter is not influenced by the formulation of the samples and the previously reported values are on agreement with the data shown in Table 2.
The moisture content data recorded against the time were fitted to Peleg model [30] to investigate the moisture adsorption kinetics of nano-biocomposites. The k1 and k2 values are reported in Table 3. The parameter k1 refers to the mass transfer, i.e., the lower the k1 value, the higher the initial water adsorption rate. The parameter k2 refers to the maximum water adsorption capacity, i.e., the lower the k2 value, the higher the water adsorption capacity.
All the nano-biocomposites tended to adsorbwater faster (lower k1) and in higher quantities (lower k2) at higher relative humidities (RH). It is well-known that for polysaccharides, themoisture equilibrium is correlated to the RH, i.e., films conditioned at higher RH take more time to reach the equilibrium. Similar behaviours have been reported for cassava starchfilms and oat starch films byMali et al. [28] and Galdeano et al. [29], respectively.
The 50:50 TPS/PBAT samples adsorbed water faster (lower k1 values) and had lower water adsorption capacity (higher k2 values) than the 80:20 TPS/PBAT samples. Samples containing greater starch content (80:20) tended to adsorb water more slowly, but in greater quantities.
In general, the sepiolite nanoclay in nano-biocomposites makes more difficult the water adsorption, reducing the water adsorption rate and the water adsorption capacity. An exception was observed for 80:20 nano-biocomposites at 90% RH, highlighting the influence of the higher relative humidity in the water adsorption rate and the water adsorption capacity of these samples.
It is recognised that sepiolite nanoclay with silanol groups has good affinity with water molecules, but increasing its concentration did not increase the water affinity of the samples, probably because the silanol groups on nanoclay surface are mobilised in interactions with starch.
A main challenge when incorporating nanoclays in biodegradable materials is related to the alteration of colour and lack of transparency that may arise from nanoclay addition. The opacity and the colour parameters of the nano-biocomposites were determined and are shown in Table 4 and Fig. 4, respectively, in order to bring additional information on these multiphase systems. The film's transparency depends on
the nanoclay content in starch matrix, where higher nanoclay content lead to more opaque films [39].
The blends presented lower opacity compared to the corresponding nano-biocomposites, and considering the TPS/PBAT blends without sepiolite, it is possible to observe that the samples containingmore starch (80:20:0)were less opaque than those containingmore PBAT (50:50:0) (Table 4). Some authors [40,41] attributed greater values of opacity to a denser matrix structure.
Sepiolite nanoclay significantly altered the nano-biocomposites colour, which became redder (increase of a* positive) and yellower (increase of b* positive) with the increase in nanoclay content in the samples until 3 wt% concentration (Fig. 4). Then, a further increase to 5wt% of nanoclay only leads to small changes in sample colour. This behaviour was similar for both 50:50 and 80:20 TPS/PBAT systems.
Sepiolite nanoclay presents as awhite powderwith a yellowish-reddish tint that was responsible for the colour differences observed in Fig. 4, taking into consideration that no influence of the sample thickness could be considered, since all the samples were compression moulded with a final thickness of 0.5 mm.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
A TPS/PBAT nano-biocomposite with good performancewas obtained by the incorporation of sepiolite as needle-like filler. Sepiolite influenced the crystallisation of nano-biocomposites, without causing interference in their crystalline organisation. An increase of 25 °C in the Tg of TPS was registered with the addition of 5 wt% of sepiolite (e.g., 50/50/5 sample). These shifts in Tg evidenced high sepiolite-starch interfacial interactions and its higher compatibility with starch.
The inclusion of sepiolite nanoclay decreased the water adsorption rate and the water adsorption capacity of nano-biocomposites, reflecting a high interaction through intermolecular links (starch/silanol groups). Lastly, higher sepiolite contents tended to elevate the opacity and changed the final colour of the materials.
This work highlights the great potential of natural sepiolite nanoclay to elaborate promising nano-biocomposites based on TPS/PBAT systems, improving different behaviours such as mechanical, thermal, and water uptake properties, producing advanced and efficient biodegradable materials. These materials combine the high content of lowcost biopolymers from agro-resources, biodegradability and/or compostability and good processability, without chemical modifications, which are great advantages for short-term applications (packaging, agriculture and hygiene).

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 29 May 2016 Received in revised form 21 August 2016 Accepted 29 August 2016 Available online 31 August 2016 The effects of sepiolite addition (0, 1, 3 and 5wt%) were evaluated on dynamic-mechanical behaviour, water uptake, thermal and optical properties of thermoplastic starch (TPS)/poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT) nano-biocomposites, with different TPS/PBAT (w/w) ratios and nanofiller contents. The results highlighted the improvement of the dynamic-mechanical behaviourwith the addition of sepiolite, producing high performance materials. An increase of 25 °C in the Tg of TPS was recorded by DMTA analysis at sepiolite content of 5 wt%. The sepiolite influenced the crystallisation of nano-biocomposites, without causing interference in the crystal organisation, evidenced by DSC analysis. The addition of sepiolite nanoclay decreased the water adsorption rate and water adsorption capacity of the corresponding nano-biocomposites. For such multiphase systems, the successful use of natural sepiolite brought a clear benefit, without the need of anymodifications or additional processes to produce advanced nano-biocomposites. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
